body: On what version of NUnit are you seeing these errors?
This is on the NUnit 3.0 framework. I ran Smart Unit Tests directly on nunit-master\nunit-master\src\NUnitFramework\framework\Attributes\RangeAttribute.cs.

We'll treat this as a bug for now and check it out further.

For the divide by zero exception, that has always seemed like a reasonable thing to happen if the user happens to specify a step of zero!

~~The issue of ordering of arguments has already been discussed extensively. This fix: https://github.com/nunit/nunit/pull/77 created code to throw an ArgumentException with an appropriate message if the order is incorrect. I'll have to check the code to see how an OverflowException is generated instead.~~
It would be helpful if you could provide an actual test that demonstrates the overflow.

The earlier comment about ArgumentException was incorrect. It applies to the RangeConstraint not the RangeAttribute. RangeAttribute gives the errors as reported:

A step of zero causes a DivideByZeroException. I think this could be replaced by an ArgumentException but is also OK as it stands. It should be clear to the developer.

Reversing from and to causes an OverflowException. We should at least throw an Argument exception with an appropriate message. Alternatively, we could make it work in various ways, as shown below.

Additionally, use of a negative step with from < to will cause an overflow. Again, we should either throw an ArgumentException or make it work.

Proposed Resolution (please comment):

A step of zero should give an argument exception. Even though DivideByZero is logical, it takes a moment to figure it out. A message like "Zero step not allowed" is much simpler.

An invalid combination of from, to and step should give an argument exception. An invalid combination occurs if from > to and the step is positive or if from < to and the step is negative.

A valid combination of from, to and step should just work. This will require a bit of change in the code for negative steps.

The three proposed solutions all make sense. It is how I would expect it to work.

That said, if it is a major rework to allow a negative step, we could just throw an argument exception and document it. I think that since no-one has ever reported it before it isn't a common thing people would think of doing. It was only reported now because of an automated testing tool.
@rprouse I agree. I lowered the priority.

I believe this can be done in steps of improvement.  
1) The documentation for RangeAttribute at http://www.nunit.org/index.php?p=range&r=2.6.3 is a bit overly optimistic "creates test cases from all possible combinations of the datapoints ".  It should be rephrased, and the limits stated.  It should also state that with wrong parameters you may get these two exceptions.
2) There is obviously something that always will go wrong, from>to & step negative and to>from and step positive.  Those two can be excluded with a guard clause throwing an argument exception.  
3) If negative steps need rework of the code, just guard that out for now, and state that in the documentation.  
4) Since it can operate on floating point numbers, a step may be too small compared to the range it operates on, causing overflow, then this could be attacked later.  I would not prioritize this, as I am fine with an overflow exception as long as it is documented.

issue.title: Add Roslyn Code Analyzers for NUnit

milestone.title: Closed Without Action
milestone.description: This milestone contains closed issues where no action was taken. This includes questions, issues that could not be reproduced, rejected ideas, invalid issues, etc.

issue.body:
Visual Studio 2015 and Roslyn introduced code analyzers and the concept of code-aware libraries. There are many ways that users can incorrectly use NUnit, so we could provide analyzers to detect incorrect usage and suggest fixes. This would help users become more productive and reduce the number of errors reported because features are incorrectly used.

If we do this, it should be a separate analyzer assembly that is a dependency of the framework NuGet package.

Some things we could check,
- Constructors and test methods are public
- TestCase attributes have the correct number and type of arguments for the given method
- If a test method has a return type, the test attribute has ExpectedResult set
- If we `Assert.That(x, Is.Not.Null)` and variants, x is a reference type
- Classes that contain tests are marked with the TestFixture attribute
- Usage of `TestCaseSource` within the same class (see #320)

Good idea? Are there other improper usages that cannot be caught at compile time that we should consider?

issue.title: Detect invalid RangeAttribute arguments. Fixes #472
issue.body:
This was laying around on my hard drive so I decided to clean it up and get it in.

I implemented the three points listed in issue #472:
1. Zero step gives an ArgumentException
2. Negative step with from < to or positive with from > to gives an Argument exception.
3. Other stuff works leaving aside Terje's comment about too small floating steps causing overflow, which is not handled in the current code.

It would be very easy to make bullet 2 work as well, by simply reversing the sign of the step. However, I haven't done that.

Docs need updating.
